awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SmartCAD: Guiding Engineering Design with Science Simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects. 

In this project, SmartCAD: Guiding Engineering Design with Science Simulations, the Concord Consortium (lead), Purdue University, and the University of Virginia investigate how real time formative feedback can be automatically composed from the results of computational analysis of student design artifacts and processes with the envisioned SmartCAD software. Through automatic feedback based on visual analytic science simulations, SmartCAD is able to guide every student at a fine-grained level, allowing teachers to focus on high-level instruction. Considering the ubiquity of CAD software in the workplace and their diffusion into precollege classrooms, this research provides timely results that could motivate the development of an entire genre of CAD-based learning environments and materials to accelerate and scale up K-12 engineering education. The project conducts design-based research on SmartCAD, which supports secondary science and engineering with three embedded computational engines capable of simulating the mechanical, thermal, and solar performance of the built environment. These engines allow SmartCAD to analyze student design artifacts on a scientific basis and provide automatic formative feedback in forms such as numbers, graphs, and visualizations to guide student design processes on an ongoing basis. 

The research hypothesis is that appropriate applications of SmartCAD in the classroom results in three learning outcomes: 1) Science knowledge gains as indicated by a deeper understanding of the involved science concepts and their integration at the completion of a design project; 2) Design competency gains as indicated by the increase of iterations, informed design decisions, and systems thinking over time; and 3) Design performance improvements as indicated by a greater chance to succeed in designing a product that meets all the specifications within a given period of time. While measuring these learning outcomes, this project also probes two research questions: 1) What types of feedback from simulations to students are effective in helping them attain the outcomes? and 2) Under what conditions do these types of feedback help students attain the outcomes? To test the research hypothesis and answer the research questions, this project develops three curriculum modules based on the Learning by Design (LBD) Framework to support three selected design challenges: Solar Farms, Green Homes, and Quake-Proof Bridges. This integration of SmartCAD and LBD situate the research in the LBD context and shed light on how SmartCAD can be used to enhance established pedagogical models such as LBD. Research instruments include knowledge integration assessments, data mining, embedded assessments, classroom observations, participant interviews, and student questionnaires. This research is carried out in Indiana, Massachusetts, and Virginia simultaneously, involving more than 2,000 secondary students at a number of socioeconomically diverse schools. Professional development workshops are provided to familiarize teachers with SmartCAD materials and implementation strategies prior to the field tests. An external Critical Review Committee consisting of five engineering education researchers and practitioners oversee and evaluate this project formatively and summative. Project materials and results are disseminated through publications, presentations, partnerships, and the Internet.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: This project's primary contribution identified under what instructional conditions SmartCAD resulted in students' integrated STEM learning. 

We determined that (a) Learning by Design was a useful pedagogical framework to integrate science experiments with engineering design; (b) argumentation prompts along with design journals supported students to connect their science learning to inform their engineering design decisions; and (c) as teachers implemented these pedagogies and scaffolding strategies along with SmartCAD, they developed technological pedagogical content knowledge. These efforts resulted in a blueprint for SmartCAD teacher workshops. These workshops provided an opportunity for the teachers to serve as design partners and refine our classroom resources.

Our curricular materials facilitated seamless learning of STEM practices. Based on a study conducted in a middle school with more than 400 students identified that they developed (a) a better understanding of the relationships between variables and underlying science concepts, (b) used various mathematical analysis tools and graphical representations embedded in the available technology to inform their engineering design decisions, (c) demonstrated idea fluency and performed systematic, controlled experiments. The learning environment afforded formative feedback to understand the relationship between variables provided converging evidence using multiple analytical tools. It also enabled visual problem decomposition using a suboptimal model. 

To explain students' differences in how they benefited from the learning materials, we investigated students' possible changes in their self-generated heuristics of science concepts before and after engaging in a design challenge using SmartCAD. We identified two groups: the naïve developing heuristic group and the semi-knowledgeable fixated heuristic group. The majority of the students in the naïve developing heuristic group demonstrated low to below basic levels of heuristics use before they participated in the learning intervention. Students in the naïve developing heuristic group showed significant learning gains after being exposed to the learning intervention. On the other hand, most of the students in the semi-knowledgeable fixated heuristic group demonstrated basic contextual and contextual levels of heuristics use.  Students in the semi-knowledgeable fixated group did not increase their performance. 

We also characterized students' experimentation strategies in engineering design using logged data from SmartCAD. The number of uncontrolled and controlled experiments suggested within a continuum from beginning designer to informed designer. We also investigated the interplay between students' design strategies use and design performance. The results indicated that students' performance in generating ideas was directly proportional to that in troubleshooting. These performances had a direct and positive influence on students' final design performance.

We then compared the effectiveness of two learning strategies that could promote design strategies.  We compared the effects of tell-and-practice and contrasting cases for eliciting design strategies use. We found that students exposed to tell-and-practice then contrasting cases had more balanced use of design strategies than the students exposed to contrasting cases then tell-and-practice. That is, the order of the intervention affected design strategies use. We also found that students spent more time experimenting and understanding how a system works rather than focusing on problematic areas and finding solutions to the problems they face during the design process.

We described three different case studies that adopted the same learning design and adapted it to particular populations, settings, and contexts in a middle-school classroom, a high-school classroom, and a pre-service teacher's classroom. We specifically focused on (a) the instructional design of a lesson that integrates science learning with engineering design skills and (b) how the corresponding in-class orchestration took place in three classrooms with middle-school, high-school, and pre-service teacher populations. Although the classroom orchestration of the particular learning design was customized for specific audiences and contexts, findings from this study suggest that the core components of the learning design and their alignment resulted in students' learning.

Research on the effectiveness of using argumentation scaffold to inform pre-service teachers' design decision-making showed that learners who used the argumentation scaffold (a) generated decision-making arguments of higher quality, (b) devoted more attention to scientific principles when they made their decision claims, (c) used more variety of combinations of evidence and reasoning to support their claims, (d) utilized more scientific principles to back up their claims, and (e) achieved slightly better performance in their final design (even though not statistically significant).

Broader Impact: In addition to new knowledge, this project generated curricular materials and lesson plans that can be easily adapted and adopted by teachers to facilitate integrated STEM learning in the classroom and professional development.  As we performed design-based research throughout this project, more than 1100 students were impacted at the K-12 level and 200 at the undergraduate level. Similarly, 120 pre-service teachers and 92 in-service teachers developed technological pedagogical content knowledge to implement these learning resources in their current and future classrooms.  Moreover, two postdoctoral associates, two doctoral students, two master students, and four undergraduate students received training in educational research methods and learning design as part of this project.
